Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male with a chief complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath. He was admitted to the ICU and started on amiodarone for arrhythmias. The patient has no known drug allergies. He received a total of 61 mL of fluids over the past 24 hours, with 500 mL of urine output. His vital signs remain stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 129/52-136/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16-23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on a nasal cannula. The patient's heart rhythm remains in sinus rhythm. The physical examination was not fully assessed due to limitations. There are no significant changes in the patient's medical or family history. Review of systems is unchanged from admission. The patient continues to receive prophylactic medications for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, the potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Arrhythmias: The patient was started on amiodarone for arrhythmias, indicating a pre-existing condition. Continuous monitoring of the heart rhythm is necessary to detect any potential arrhythmias.
2. Fluid imbalance: The patient has received a total of 61 mL of fluids over the past 24 hours, which may indicate a fluid imbalance.

They are currently on various other medications. There are no changes to their medical and family history. The patient's review of systems remains unchanged from admission, except as noted below.

Vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 133/57 to 136/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's heart rhythm is in sinus rhythm. Hemodynamic monitoring shows a fluid balance of 61 mL in since 12 AM, with total input of 61 mL and total output of 18 mL. Blood products were not given, and the patient had a urine output of 500 mL. No NG tube, stool, or drain output was recorded. The respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a nasal cannula, with a SpO2 of 97%. The ABG results are not provided in the note.

Physical examination findings include peripheral vascular assessment of right and left radial pulses, right and left digital peripheral pulses, skin assessment, neurologic assessment, and assessment of movement, tone, and responsiveness, all of which were not assessed.

0.5 mg/min Other ICU medications: Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2133-11-21**] 11:19 PM Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) - [**2133-11-21**] 11:20 PM Other medications: Magnesium Sulfate IV Sliding Scale Atorvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO BID Terazosin 2 mg PO HS Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY Amiodarone 400 mg PO BID Start: In am Amiodarone 0.5 mg/min IV INFUSION Heparin 5000 UNIT SC TID Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN Changes to medical and family history: Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below Review of systems: Flowsheet Data as of [**2133-11-22**] 07:53 AM Vital signs Hemodynamic monitoring Fluid balance 24 hours Since 12 AM Tmax: 36.8 C (98.2 Tcurrent: 36.7 C (98 HR: 70 (53 - 73) bpm BP: 130/70(83) {113/41(59) - 148/70(92)} mmHg RR: 19 (16 - 23) insp/min SpO2: 96% Heart rhythm: SR (Sinus Rhythm) Total In: 61 mL 176 mL PO: TF: IVF: 61 mL 176 mL Blood products: Total out: 0 mL 1,250 mL Urine: 1,250 mL NG: Stool: Drains: Balance: 61 mL -1,074 mL Respiratory support O2 Delivery Device: Nasal cannula SpO2: 96% ABG: ///25/ Physical Examination General Appearance: Well nourished, No acute distress Head, Ears, Nose, Throat: JVD to mandible Cardiovascular: (S2: Normal), irregular rate Peripheral Vascular: (Right radial pulse: Not assessed), (Left radial pulse: Not assessed), (Right DP pulse: Not assessed), (Left DP pulse: Not assessed) Respiratory / Chest: (Expansion: Symmetric), (Breath Sounds: Clear : ) Abdominal: Soft, Non-tender, Bowel sounds present Extremities: Right: 2+, Left: 2+ Skin: Not assessed Neurologic: Responds to: Not assessed, Movement: Not assessed, Tone: Not assessed Labs / Radiology 134 K/uL 12.0 g/dL 96 mg/dL 1.5 mg/dL 25 mEq/L 3.5 mEq/L 21 mg/dL 106 mEq/L 140 mEq/L 33.1 % 6.8 K/uL [image002.jpg] [**2133-11-22**] 02:16 AM WBC 6.8 Hct 33.1 Plt 134 Cr 1.5 TropT 0.02 Glucose 96 Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.9/27.1/1.2, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:102/4/0.02, Differential-Neuts:64.6 %, Lymph:27.7 %, Mono:4.7 %, Eos:2.7 %, Ca++:8.4 mg/dL, Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:3.2 mg/dL Assessment and Plan Mr [**Known lastname 2633**] is a 76 year old man with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia and CAD, s/p DES to LAD, presenting with worsening dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema and atrial bigeminy with NSVT. . # Dizziness / NSVT : Given findings of bradycardia and NSVT, most likely cause of symptoms is hypoperfusion. Although [**Location (un) 250**] documentation reports bradycardia however, it is noted that there is a discrepance between pulse and electrocardiographically recorded rate; this is likely secondary to bigeminy which prevents differentiation of the two closely spaced beats and dose not represent true bradycardia.
Regarding VT/NSVT, given history of three vessel disease, it is likely that this represents new ischemic event, likely silent and subacute leading to left ventricular scar given right bundle morphology of VT.
Differential for new VT includes scar mediated as above, as well as ischemic, electrolyte disorders and medication side effects. Admission labs however seems to point away from active ischemia and electrolyte disorders as etiology. -- Rule out for MI with serial enzmes -- ECHO Tuesday -- Continue Amiodarone, finish IV load overnight -- Obtain TFT's, LFT's. -- Continue aspirin -- Continue beta blocker given concern for ischemia, although at reduced dose given amiodarone load. -- Anticipate cardiac catheterization monday. -- Diuresis . # RIGHT VENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC FAILURE: Physical exam suggestive of right sided volume overload without significant pulmonary edema, although hilar lymphadenopathy suggests some chronic congestion. Possible unifying diagnosis to consider is recent ischemic event leading to symptomatic systolic heart failure as well as scar formation. -- ECHO as above -- IV Lasix, start with 10mg IV given pt is lasix naive -- Rule out MI as above -- Goal 1L negative overnight . # Chronic Renal Failure: Unclear what patien't baseline is currently, although [**Location (un) 250**] labs with creatinine of 1.6 in [**2131**]. -- Avoid nephrotoxic medications -- Monitor closely . # Hypertension: Hold amlodipine at this time, would favor using ACEI given concern for both excessive nodal agents and new systolic heart failure. . # GOUT: Not active at this time. . # ALCOHOL USE: Although low concern for abuse, given age withdrawal at low doses is possible. -- Monitor closely -- Although would consider benzos if patient is agitated, would avoid them for now given concern for delirium. . FEN: Cardiac diet ACCESS: PIV's PROPHYLAXIS: -DVT ppx with SC Heparin -Pain managment with Tylenol -Bowel regimen CODE: Full DISPO: CCU for now. . ICU Care Nutrition: Glycemic Control: Lines: 18 Gauge - [**2133-11-21**] 09:43 PM Prophylaxis: DVT: Stress ulcer: VAP: Comments: Communication: Comments: Code status: Disposition:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD), who has undergone a percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (DES) to the left anterior descending artery (LAD). He presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, and atrial bigeminy with nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT). The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate (HR) of 70 bpm, blood pressure (BP) ranging from 130/70 mmHg to 148/70 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 96%. The patient is receiving amiodarone infusion and heparin sodium prophylaxis.

Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention (JVD) to the mandible, irregular heart rhythm with an S2 heart sound, and bilateral lower extremity edema. The patient's breath sounds are clear and symmetric, with no signs of respiratory distress. Neurological examination is not assessed.

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and CAD, who presented with worsening dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, and atrial bigeminy with nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT). The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 51 bpm (with a range of 51-83 bpm), blood pressure ranging from 127/47 mmHg to 166/101 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute (with a range of 16-26 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is on prophylactic heparin sodium.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.8 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 12.0 g/dL, platelet count of 134 K/uL, creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, troponin T level of 0.02 ng/mL, blood glucose level of 96 mg/dL, and sodium level of 139 mEq/L. The patient's ECG shows NSVT with a right bundle branch morphology.
